definition:
Let $W(\mathbb{R}^d)$ be Wiener space. The *Cameron-Martin space*
$H(\mathbb{R}^d)$ is the subspace of $W(\mathbb{R}^d)$ consisting of all
paths $\omega$ such that $\omega$ is absolutely continuous and
$\int_0^\infty |\omega'(s)|^2\,ds < \infty$. (Note that if $\omega$ is
absolutely continuous, then it is almost everywhere differentiable, so
the integral makes sense.)

This can be thought of as the set of paths with “finite energy.”

Note that $H(\mathbb{R}^d)$ has Wiener measure $0$, since sample paths
of Brownian motion are nowhere differentiable, whereas a path from
$H(\mathbb{R}^d)$ is almost everywhere differentiable.
